Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I think most people would like to know where their money is coming from.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> How would you regulate fraud in the blockchain utopia?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> or possible money laundering and corruption?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> If you have ideas i'd like to hear them. It's an interesting topic. You have to play devils advocate though. If noone used KYC and everyone used anonymous transactions, there could be all sorts of possible problems.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> You need to assume innocence first. How detectives work?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Ok so if a drug dealer sends you payment for a house, and you received a non-kyc contract with payment from an anonymous source. How could we prevent this from happening?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> KYC kills the innocence principle.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> ask the drug addict whom he bought from

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> it worked like that for centuries, now all of a sudden KYC is ubiquitous and a supposed panacea

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> so you would willingly accept money that was obtained with illicit sources. it doesnt have any moral reprehension on you?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> or would you rather make sure the funds come from licit sources prior to signing the contract?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> I worked for the money, it is legally mine. No moral problem there, as long as I collaborate with the security forces. But always respecting the innocence principle.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> Even if the police find the drug dealer culprit, my money is clean, as he wasn't declared a criminal yet.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> You're completely forgetting about the innocence principle, and that's what is this all about.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> Nobody's innocent, nobody's free.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> In a full KYC world, prisons are not needed, as the whole world is a prison.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> "Criminals" would just be less favored prisoners.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I'm not following your logic. what i was referring to was the ability to auto-regulate our activity, transactions, and interactions to minimize overwhelming intrusion from government. However, not knowing who you are transacting with is not ideal 99% of the time. As proven with Komodo Z addresses holding 0.01% of funds.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I would like to see decentralized KYC that we can all use ourselves to determine and allows us to comply with basic KYC/AML which means knowing someones name, address, and that they are not on a terrorist list. If you see that the transaction is coming from someone unsavory or it's an anonymous transaction, it's your choice to accept it or deny it based o its source.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> How can you trust a "terrorist list" from a government that creates terrorists but says to fight them?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> that's up to you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> but the choice is there

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> Exactly, just like with no KYC at all.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> with no KYC you can't know anything. how can you make an informed decision when part of the information is missing.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> unless we self enforce it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> which is what i'm talking about.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <LoboRei> Terror is a perceptional quality. Anybody including those meant to safeguard us could be deemed terrorists

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> So are we to ignore there are bad people in the world that want to steal everything you have or destroy it?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> It is not your duty to condemn them. They are innocent until proven otherwise. KYC subverts that principle. 
You should only "freeze" or give up funds, at judicial order.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> (Or block someone, or anything.)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> For arguments sake, let's say a person was convicted of a financial crime and stole millions from a pension. And he is on the run. He is on a list that you can check in order to filter any tenants or business partners. He wants to rent or buy your apartment. If you don't check it, you have now done business with a criminal.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> Was he sentenced?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Maybe

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> at this point he is on the list

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> "Maybe", that's the problem.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> being looked for by various jurisidictions according to our blockchain police explorer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Ok, so you ignore the facts and transact with him anyway.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> the kyc didn't stop you from doing business with him

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> it just informed you so you can make a better decision.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> it's a tool

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> KYC != sentenced people list.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> we need to rethink KYC and how it's applied instead of demonizing it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> 1 reason is because it's not going away.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> and 2 is because blockchain will change the way kyc works

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> "we need to think how to collaborate better with this dictatorship, reason 1 - it is not going away"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> same logic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> So KYC  equals  Dictatorship?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I don't follow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> yes, because it presumes everyone is guilty until proven otherwise.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> :PeepoThink:

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> if kyc presumed us guilty, why are we most of us still able to our banks, paypal, and, western union accounts.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> as i said before, you're a very privileged prisoner

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Can we agree there are extremes to KYC?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> What about decentralized forms of KYC?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> what about unicorns?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I guess wake me up when we live in the blockchain utopia with no kyc and enforced anonymity for everyone.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I'll build some services for people ðŸ˜„

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> Of course, integration with the current systems and structures will help, i'm not blaming you for doing so.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> I just can't accept KYC as something inherently good. It is not. It is the opposite of good.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I understand where you coming from. The philosophy of it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <stock999> KYC just doesn't work in order to restrict crime. Drug dealer will never act by own name, he will find innocent relatives, friends, etc.  As well as a person suspected in financial crime  will open an offshore company  with a nominal director, who is clean and honest.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I understand what you mean, but you're also talking about extremes.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> The reality is that it's not going away. So better KYC implementations need to come along that dont' put people's identities in the hands of hackers or centralized parties.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <stock999> There are many ways how to hide the real face, except blockchain.  May be honest people just don't think about it, but criminals know very well all these methods and use it successfully.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Those methods you point out are legal loopholes created by the financial system and governments that aid them.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> So in essence, people that use those loopholes don't break any laws. That isn't KYC's fault, it's the system.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> like i said, KYC is just a tool.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> And they don't care, because, again, they lie when they say that it is to catch the bad boys. The bad boys aren't fools. It is meant for the regular user, the innocent trader. To control them. To posses them. To subjugate them.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Basic KYC is knowing a persons identity. That could be on either extreme. It could be an encrypted hash that tells you this person is not on a criminal list but doesn't give you any further information, or it could give you every detail of their life. I lean towards kyc that doesn't give all the information.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> We're talking about unicorns again.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> If we talk about no kyc it's worst than unicorns

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> because it's not going away

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> No KYC was the default mode for life for centuries. It works.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> unless the world changes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> Ok

Problem is governments and sovereignty.

Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> True, that's why I accept working with KYC stuff for now, but I can't see it as anything but a necessary temporary evil.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> But the system is indeed broken. You can see it just be seeing how the rich live when compared to the majority of other people in the world.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> I've experienced it in my country. It's disgusting.

Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> I agree with that, but always consider inertial forces. The system is not always to blame, but the history is.

Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> History and inertial culture.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-cz] <Emmanuel> You learned how to deal with a computer. Where I am right now people live with cents in their pockets for months, but they would never accept a free lesson on programming or computers. They don't like it.

Content: [dscrd-cz] <PTYX> something I feel strongly about doing is bringing technology to the kids that really could use it to make something of themselves. if everything goes as planned it will be something the project will encourage.
